content.question: For parts of the free response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate.For parts of the free response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate.Answer the following questions about atomic structure and bonding.(a) Write the complete ground-state electron configuration of the <math alttext="K r" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>Kr</mi></math> atom.

frqParts.text: For parts of the free response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate.For parts of the free response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate.Answer the following questions about atomic structure and bonding.(a) Write the complete ground-state electron configuration of the <math alttext="K r" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>Kr</mi></math> atom.

(b) The <math alttext="R b with a positive 1 charge" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msup><mi>Rb</mi><mo>+</mo></msup></math> ion has the same electron configuration as the neutral <math alttext="K r" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>Kr</mi></math> atom. Which has the larger radius, the <math alttext="R b with a positive 1 charge" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msup><mi>Rb</mi><mo>+</mo></msup></math> ion or the <math alttext="K r" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>Kr</mi></math> atom? Justify your answer in terms of Coulombâ€™s law.

(c) The composition of a sample of solid <math alttext="R b" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>Rb</mi></math> containing a high percentage of the radioactive isotope <math alttext="R b 83" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>Rb</mi><mtext>-</mtext><mn>83</mn></math> is given in the following table.IsotopeIsotopic Mass <math alttext="(in atomic mass units)" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mfenced><mtext>amu</mtext></mfenced></math>Percentage of SampleIsotope Half-Life<math alttext="R b 83" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>Rb</mi><mtext>-</mtext><mo> </mo><mspace width="-0.2em"></mspace><mo> </mo><mn>83</mn></math><math alttext="82.92" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>82.92</mn></math><math alttext="32.5%" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>32.5</mn><mo>%</mo></math><math alttext="86 days" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>86</mn><mo> </mo><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mi>days</mi></math><math alttext="R b 85" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>Rb</mi><mtext>-</mtext><mn>85</mn></math><math alttext="84.91" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>84.91</mn></math><math alttext="50.8%" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>50.8</mn><mo>%</mo></math> stable<math alttext="R b 87" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>Rb</mi><mtext>-</mtext><mn>87</mn></math><math alttext="86.91" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>86.91</mn></math><math alttext="16.7%" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>16.7</mn><mo>%</mo></math> stable(i) Using the values in the table, calculate the average atomic mass, in amu, of <math alttext="R b" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>Rb</mi></math> in the sample.

(ii) <math alttext="R b 83" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>Rb</mi><mtext>-</mtext><mn>83</mn></math> undergoes radioactive decay into gaseous <math alttext="K r 83" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>Kr</mi><mtext>-</mtext><mn>83</mn></math>, which leaves the solid sample. Over time, how will the average atomic mass of the remaining sample compare to the value calculated in part (c)(i) ?

skill.text: 2.B: Formulate a hypothesis or predict the results of an experiment.
